articles.headline: Wall Street’s Fears on Lehman Bros. Batter Markets
articles.snippet: Investors were gripped by fears that another big financial institution might founder — and that the government might not come to the rescue.
articles.abstract: Investors were gripped by fears that another big financial institution might founder — and that the government might not come to the rescue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only days after the Bush administration assumed control of the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies, Wall Street was gripped by fears that another big financial institution, the investment bank Lehman Brothers, might founder  and that this time, the government might not come to the rescue.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Ben White

articles.headline: Marketing Code for Student Lenders
articles.snippet: The agreement was part of a settlement of claims that they misled consumers about loan terms and benefits.
articles.abstract: The agreement was part of a settlement of claims that they misled consumers about loan terms and benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Resolving an investigation into whether they misled consumers, seven student loan companies have agreed to follow a code of conduct for their marketing, the New York attorney general’s office said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: OPEC Takes Steps to Cut Oil Production
articles.snippet: Oil producers call for compliance with quotas, effectively cutting output if members follow through with the decision.
articles.abstract: Oil producers call for compliance with quotas, effectively cutting output if members follow through with the decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA  In an unexpected decision made after a six-hour meeting that lasted well into the night, the OPEC oil cartel said it would reduce its oil production by about half a million barrels a day in a bid to stem a rapid decline in oil prices in recent weeks.

articles.headline: Thrift Shops Thriving, but Running Low on Stock
articles.snippet: The same economic woes that are sending buyers to thrift stores are causing donors to hand over fewer items, so that many stores are running low on inventory.
articles.abstract: The same economic woes that are sending buyers to thrift stores are causing donors to hand over fewer items, so that many stores are running low on inventory.
articles.lead_paragraph: While the nation’s best-known retail chains are pulling out all the stops to lure shoppers and bolster their abysmal sales, their customers are defecting to an unlikely rival: the local thrift shop.

articles.headline: Learning to Share
articles.snippet: Parents may fear discussing who’s getting what of the family fortune. But not discussing it can be worse.
articles.abstract: Parents may fear discussing who’s getting what of the family fortune. But not discussing it can be worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE day will come, or may have already, when your children think of your money as theirs.

articles.headline: Boeing’s Strong Results Alter Strike Dynamics
articles.snippet: In struggling industries like automobiles and airlines, the bargaining power of unions has been limited by the weak positions of their employers. By contrast, Boeing is strong.
articles.abstract: In struggling industries like automobiles and airlines, the bargaining power of unions has been limited by the weak positions of their employers. By contrast, Boeing is strong.
articles.lead_paragraph: The machinists’ union walkout against the Boeing Company does not appear to fit the usual script for a modern-day labor showdown.

articles.headline: Miles of Aisles for Milk? Not Here
articles.snippet: After years of building bigger grocery stores, retailers are experimenting with radically smaller ones.
articles.abstract: After years of building bigger grocery stores, retailers are experimenting with radically smaller ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARMAR TOWNSHIP, Pa.  Like cars and homes, grocery stores are beginning to shrink.

articles.headline: ’08 Rivals Have Ties to Loan Giants
articles.snippet: Senators Obama and McCain each cite the mess at Fannie and Freddie as a consequence of lobbying, but each has ties of his own.
articles.abstract: Senators Obama and McCain each cite the mess at Fannie and Freddie as a consequence of lobbying, but each has ties of his own.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senators Barack Obama and John McCain each cite the mess at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac as a consequence of the corrosive coziness of lobbyists and politicians that they promise to end. But each man and his party also have ties to the fallen giants that will complicate the next president’s job of reshaping the mortgage finance companies that have been essential to the economy.

articles.headline: Lehman Said to Be Looking for a Buyer as Pressure Builds
articles.snippet: Potential suitors, including Barclays and Bank of America, are said to be seeking help from the Fed to make an acquisition palatable.
articles.abstract: Potential suitors, including Barclays and Bank of America, are said to be seeking help from the Fed to make an acquisition palatable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only a day ago, the head of Lehman Brothers, the beleaguered investment bank, sought to assure Wall Street that the firm could survive on its own.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Andrew Ross Sorkin
